methodology.framework: Comparative mythology + I Ching-based Human Design system
academic_foundations: I Ching (64 hexagrams → 64 Human Design gates)
Cross-cultural dragon mythology (Mesopotamian, Chinese, European, Norse, Greek)
methodology.source_standards: Ancient texts with named translators, published books with ISBNs, evidence typing (direct/inferred/symbolic), consensus levels documented. V4: Uses provisional (location_hint + summary) vs locked (page + quote) citation status. Optimized for fully accessible online sources. Relaxed trait coverage for low-consensus characteristics.

human_design_foundations: I Ching - 3,000+ years of scholarship (Wilhelm, Legge, Jung)
64 DNA codons - Nobel Prize research (Nirenberg, Khorana 1968)
Chakra system - Religious Studies, Yoga Studies
mathematical_correspondences: Binary yin/yang logic = Binary genetic code (A/T, C/G)

characteristics.trait: Cross-cultural dragon mythology: primordial chaos, power, and guardianship

counter_evidence.title: An Instinct for Dragons
counter_evidence.author: David E. Jones
counter_evidence.location_hint: Chapters on evolutionary psychology of dragon myths
counter_evidence.summary: Dragon myths arise from evolutionary fear responses to predators (raptors, cats, pythons), not extraterrestrial contact

disputed_points.consensus: low - Fringe theory not academically accepted; dragon myths have evolutionary/psychological and cultural/mythological explanations

east_west_duality: Eastern dragons (Chinese, Japanese) = wisdom, benevolence, imperial power, yang energy, water deities, bringers of rain and prosperity. Western dragons (European, Norse) = chaos, greed, destruction, treasure hoarders, malevolent forces requiring heroic conquest. This duality reflects contrasting cultural values and cosmologies.
research_notes: Ancient dragon mythology provides solid cross-cultural foundation with HIGH ancient support. Chinese dragons embody yang energy, imperial authority, and cosmic order. European/Norse dragons represent chaos, greed (Fafnir), and primordial destruction (Níðhöggr). Mesopotamian Tiamat establishes primordial chaos theme. Greek Ladon guards sacred apples. Modern reptilian theories are controversial and disputed, marked as LOW consensus with UNKNOWN ancient support. Thuban (Alpha Draconis) was ancient pole star 3942-1793 BC, giving Draco astronomical/historical significance. No conflation with kundalini serpent (avoided common stretch). Strong evidence for power, hierarchy, guardianship, transformation, and East/West duality themes.

ancient_texts: Enuma Elish - Babylonian creation epic, Tiamat as primordial chaos dragon (L. W. King translation, 1902)
Beowulf - Old English epic, dragon as treasure hoarder and chaos force (R. K. Gordon translation, 1913)
Classic of Mountains and Seas (Shanhaijing) - Chinese dragon mythology as benevolent water deities
modern_research: King, L. W. (1902). The Seven Tablets of Creation, Volume I. London: Luzac and Co.
de Visser, M. W. (1913). The Dragon in China and Japan. Amsterdam: Johannes Müller.
Shuker, K. (1995). Dragons: A Natural History. New York: Simon & Schuster. ISBN 0-684-81443-9.
Fontenrose, J. (1980). Python: A Study of Delphic Myth and Its Origins. Berkeley: University of California Press. ISBN 0-520-04091-0.
Jones, D. E. (2000). An Instinct for Dragons. New York: Routledge. ISBN 0-415-93721-8.
controversial_sources: Icke, D. (1999). The Biggest Secret. Isle of Wight: Bridge of Love Publications. ISBN 0-9526147-6-6. (DISPUTED - Reptilian conspiracy theories)
Swerdlow, S. A. (2002). Blue Blood, True Blood: Conflict and Creation. St. Joseph, MI: Expansions Publishing Company. ISBN 0-9626446-6-8. (DISPUTED - Alien genetic manipulation claims)
academic_foundations: Wilhelm, R. & Baynes, C.F. (1950). The I Ching. Princeton: Princeton University Press.
Nirenberg, M.W. & Khorana, H.G. (1968). Genetic Code Research (Nobel Prize).
Scholem, G. (1941). Major Trends in Jewish Mysticism. New York: Schocken Books.
